- I tried adjusting the alpha of plot_connectome function and it did not adjust the transparency of the brain image. 

- And can the function display the node names? 

Thank you
title: cannot adjust plot_connectome

text:
Indeed, the alpha controls the foreground but not the background. If you
want such fine control, I suggest that you save as SVG and edit the
resulting SVG.

title: title

text:
Hi folks.
I have noticed a difference between `plot_anat` and `plot_roi` regarding the size in which the brain is displayed. With `plot_roi` it nearly fills the entire image, with `plot_anat` it is much smaller.
Is there a way to zoom in on the `plot_anat` images as well? Thanks.

`plot_roi`
![plot_roi](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5772811/25886858/cc9d9bfe-355f-11e7-8775-a1dab44586d0.png)
`plot_anat`
![plot_anat](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5772811/25886857/cc9c54b0-355f-11e7-9909-318c6a3927e8.png)
title: add_contours shrinks brain

text:
It could be because plot_roi has a tiny threshold by default and hence removes the background. Try adding a small threshold to your plot_anat 

⁣Sent from my phone, please excuse typos and briefness​

On May 10, 2017, 09:11, at 09:11, Franz Liem <notifications@github.com> wrote:
>Hi folks.
>I have noticed a difference between `plot_anat` and `plot_roi`
>regarding the size in which the brain is displayed. With `plot_roi` it
>nearly fills the entire image, with `plot_anat` it is much smaller.
>Is there a way to zoom in on the `plot_anat` images as well? Thanks.
>
>`plot_roi`
>![plot_roi](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5772811/25886858/cc9d9bfe-355f-11e7-8775-a1dab44586d0.png)
>`plot_anat`
>![plot_anat](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5772811/25886857/cc9c54b0-355f-11e7-9909-318c6a3927e8.png)
>
>
>-- 
>You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
>Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
>https://github.com/nilearn/nilearn/issues/1450

Yes, indeed, contours has this bug (can you change the title, please).

Basically, we need to use better the get_bounds mechanism in the
add_contours method of the objects in displays.py to set a tighter
bounding box, as we do in the _map_show method.

On Wed, May 10, 2017 at 01:30:34AM -0700, Franz Liem wrote:
> Sorry to reopen.
> While plot_anat displays the brain large if I add threshold=1e-6, adding a
> contour to the display shrinks it back again. Adding a threshold to
> the.add_contours call doesn't help. Thanks!

> display = plotting.plot_anat(brain, threshold=1e-6)
> display.add_contours(contour, colors='r', threshold=1e-6)

> contours.pdf

> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.*


-- 
    Gael Varoquaux
    Researcher, INRIA Parietal
    NeuroSpin/CEA Saclay , Bat 145, 91191 Gif-sur-Yvette France
    Phone:  ++ 33-1-69-08-79-68
    http://gael-varoquaux.info            http://twitter.com/GaelVaroquaux

>     Basically, we need to use better the get_bounds mechanism in the
>     add_contours method of the objects in displays.py to set a tighter bounding
>     box, as we do in the _map_show method.

> AFAIK, add_contours itself uses _map_show method.

Good point. So what we should do would be, in map_show, to set a
threshold a bit below the minimum contour, so that the mechanism of
bounding box is reused.

I've tried something in this direction in
https://github.com/nilearn/nilearn/pull/1459 . It's a rough sketch done
while listening to a talk. @fliem, can you check that it solves your
problem.
Reopening, as we haven't merged my PR
That works. Thanks Gael.

Sorry to reopen.
While `plot_anat` displays the brain large if I add `threshold=1e-6`, adding a contour to the display shrinks it back again. Adding a threshold to the`.add_contours` call  doesn't help. Thanks!
```
display = plotting.plot_anat(brain, threshold=1e-6)
display.add_contours(contour, colors='r', threshold=1e-6)
```
![contours.pdf](https://github.com/nilearn/nilearn/files/989167/contours.pdf)

Thanks su much @GaelVaroquaux. That looks good!
![contours](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5772811/26551741/3a4ba19a-4484-11e7-8b05-41c746cedfd5.png)

Great. Once I get @KamalakerDadi's +1, we'll merge.
LGTM.
Output still looks good.

I had a quick look at the plot_prob_atlas example. There is some problem with displaying contours.For instance, a msdl atlas in https://2495-1235740-gh.circle-artifacts.com/0/home/ubuntu/nilearn/doc/_build/html/auto_examples/01_plotting/plot_prob_atlas.html#sphx-glr-auto-examples-01-plotting-plot-prob-atlas-py

In plot_prob_atlas, we add an heuristic to get the threshold (levels) for displaying. May be we are double thresholding. I might also be wrong. I can have a closer look in more detail, later.
Do you have any tests to add ?
+1 from my side. Merging this one.

title: title

text:
```py
import numpy as np

import nibabel

from nilearn.plotting import plot_stat_map
from nilearn.image import new_img_like
from nilearn.image import resample_img

img = 'image_12099.nii.gz'
affine = np.diag([-3, 3, 3])
cut_coords = (0, 0, 0)

plot_stat_map(img, cut_coords=cut_coords, title='original image')

img_resampled = resample_img(img, target_affine=affine)
plot_stat_map(img_resampled, cut_coords=(0, 0, 0), title='resampled image')

img = nibabel.load(img)
data = img.get_data().astype('f8')
new_img_little_endian = new_img_like(img, data)
img_resampled_little_endian = resample_img(new_img_little_endian, target_affine=affine)

plot_stat_map(img_resampled_little_endian, cut_coords=cut_coords,
              title='resample image with little-endian type')


```

The image is [image_12099.nii.gz](https://github.com/nilearn/nilearn/files/976184/image_12099.nii.gz).

![original](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1680079/25704776/1a2554c2-30db-11e7-8793-a079f8b2ca4a.png)
![resampled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1680079/25704770/1673d8ee-30db-11e7-9d03-9755a46023b2.png)
![resampled-from-little-endian](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1680079/25704768/13dc86ee-30db-11e7-955a-f257a651d349.png)

If you look at the resampled data, you have some NaNs and big values of the order of `1e308`. It seems like the culprit is that the scipy functions we are using don't deal well with big-endian dtypes on my little-endian machine.
title: resample_img problem with big-endian data on a little-endian machine
resample_img problem with big-endian data on a little-endian machine

text: FYI I opened https://github.com/scipy/scipy/issues/7388 in the scipy tracker. The problem is very similar to the one we had 2+ years ago, except that this one happens when the affine passed into `ndimage.affine_transform` is 1d. The fix I did at the time only fixed the case where affine` is 2d :cry:
